We borrow some function names from R to indicate the corresponding probability functions   ***dmultinom*** (for the multinomial distribution) ,  
and a density function ***ddirichlet*** (for the Dirichlet distribution).

We let $Dir$ be the Dirichlet distribution normalizer constant, defined by 

$$
\begin{aligned}
Dir({a_1},{a_2},{a_3},{a_4}) 
 & = \frac{{Gamma({a_1})Gamma({a_2})Gamma({a_3})Gamma({a_4})}}{{Gamma\left( {\sum\limits_i {{a_i}} } \right)}}\\\\
 & = \frac{{({a_1} - 1)!({a_2} - 1)!({a_3} - 1)!({a_4} - 1)!}}
 {{\left( {\sum\limits_i {{a_i}}  - 1} \right)!}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $Gamma$ is the standard gamma function, with the convenient property $Gamma(n) = (n-1)!$.

$$
\begin{array}{*{20}{l}}
\begin{array}{l}
{m_{Split}} = \Pr ({\bf{n}}|\phi  = Split) = \int\limits_{\bf{p}} {} \Pr ({\bf{n}}|{\bf{p}},\phi  = Split)\Pr ({\bf{p}})\\\\
 = \int\limits_{\bf{p}} {} dmultinom({\bf{n}},{\bf{p}}) \cdot ddirichlet({\bf{p}},{\bf{a}})
\end{array}\\\\
{ = \int\limits_{\bf{p}} {\left( {\frac{{n!}}{{{n_{RD}}!{n_{ND}}!{n_{RL}}!{n_{NL}}!}}p_{RD}^{{n_{RD}}} \cdot p_{ND}^{{n_{ND}}} \cdot p_{RL}^{{n_{RL}}} \cdot p_{NL}^{{n_{NL}}}} \right)}  \cdot \frac{p_{RD}^{{a_{RD}} - 1} \cdot p_{ND}^{{a_{ND}} - 1} \cdot p_{RL}^{{a_{RL}} - 1} \cdot p_{NL}^{{a_{NL}} - 1}}{Dir({\bf{a}})}}
\end{array}
$$

For the original data, this is

 $$
 \begin{aligned}
{m_{Split}} & = \frac{{100!}}{{3!2!5!90!}}Dir(4,3,6,91){Dir^{ - 1}}(1,1,1,1)\\\\
{\rm{    }} & = \frac{{100!}}{{103!}}3!\\\\
{\rm{    }} & = 5.654477 \times 10^{ -6}
\end{aligned}
$$
